Cloze

fields:
What type of hypersensitivity is Graves disease?

{{c1::Type II (antibody-mediated)}}
The alveoli contain phagocytic cells called {{c1::alveolar macrophages}}, which clear debris and participate in the immune response
macrophages fill with debris and migrate to the bronchioles, where they are cleared via the mucociliary escalator

What type of hypersensitivity reaction occurs in polyarteritis nodosa? 

{{c1::Type III (immune-complex mediated)}}

{{c4::Fat}} emboli are characterized by a triad of:

- {{c1::hypox}}emia
- {{c2::neurologic}} abnormalities
- {{c3::petechial rash overlying the chest}}

These symptoms are seen 1-3 days after the injury

- fat globules can escape lungs by opening precapillary arteriovenous shunts that open due to increased pulmonary artery pressure (allowing dissemination to the brain --> confusion and neurologic abnormalities)

- once past lungs, may disseminate to dermal capillaries; petechial rash due to thrombocytopenia (platelets adhere to and coat fat macroglobules)

- anemia is also seen, due to increased RBC aggregation / destruction, as well as possible pulmonary hemorrhage
Club (clara) cells of the lung secrete a component of {{c1::surfactant}} and act as reserve cells
Surfacent is a detergent and has anti microbial properties
Club (clara) cells of the lung may degrade {{c1::toxins}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis? 

{{c1::Type III (immune complex-mediated)}}
The granules of basophils/mast cells contain {{c1::heparin}} and {{c2::histamine}} (anticoagulant and vasodilator, respectively)

Histamine which causes smooth muscle constriction in the bronchus and g.i. tract or smooth muscle relaxation in the vasculature – depending on the type or receptor engaged in the tissue involved. The result clinically of histamine release is an increased vascular permeability and edema, pruritus, and increased exocrine secretions
{{c1::Plasma}} cells produce a large amount of antibody specific to a particular antigen
Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the {{c1::yolk sac}} from {{c2::3}} to {{c2::8 weeks}}
progression of erythopoiesis: "Young Liver Synthesizes Blood" (Yolk Sac, Liver, Spleen, and Bone marrow)
Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the {{c1::liver}} from {{c2::6 weeks}} to {{c2::birth}}
progression of erythopoiesis: "Young Liver Synthesizes Blood" (Yolk Sac, Liver, Spleen, and Bone marrow)
Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the {{c1::spleen}} from {{c2::10}} to {{c2::28 weeks}}
progression of erythopoiesis: "Young Liver Synthesizes Blood" (Yolk Sac, Liver, Spleen, and Bone marrow)
Fetal erythropoiesis occurs in the {{c1::bone marrow}} from {{c2::18 weeks}} to {{c2::adulthood}}
progression of erythopoiesis: "Young Liver Synthesizes Blood" (Yolk Sac, Liver, Spleen, and Bone marrow)
The {{c3::CD34+::CD Marker}} hematopoietic stem cell may differentiate into a {{c1::myeloid}} or {{c2::lymphoid}} stem cell

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is chronic autoimmune gastritis? 

{{c1::Type IV (T-cell mediated)}}
antibodies (e.g. anti-IF, parietal cell) are a consequence of the mucosal damage, NOT the cause
{{c2::Celiac}} disease is immune-mediated damage of small bowel villi due to {{c1::gluten}} exposure
gluten is present in wheat and grains; also known as gluten-sensitive enteropathy and celiac sprue
Celiac disease is associated with HLA-{{c1::DQ2}} and HLA-{{c1::DQ8}}

What malabsorption disorder is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8? 

{{c1::Celiac disease}}

What is the most pathogenic component of gluten (celiac disease)?

{{c1::Gliadin}}
Once absorbed, gliadin is deamidated by the enzyme {{c1::tissue transglutaminase (tTG)}}

APCs can endocytose deamidated gliadin (and gliadin- TG2 complexes) for processing and presentation: Deamidated gliadin peptides bind strongly to two Class II MHC molecules: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 which activate gluten-specific TH1 cells and lead to secretion of IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha
In Celiac disease, {{c1::deamidated gliadin}} is presented by APCs via MHC class II

Which immune cell mediates the tissue damage in Celiac disease? 

{{c1:: Th2 cells}}
Celiac disease in {{c1::children}} (age group) classically presents as abdominal distention, steatorrhea, and failure to thrive
Celiac disease in {{c1::adults}} (age group) classically presents with chronic steatorrhea and bloating
{{c4::Celiac}} disease is classically associated with Ig{{c5::A}} antibodies against {{c1::endomysium}}, {{c2::tissue transglutaminase (tTG)}}, and/or {{c3::deamidated gliadin}}
In patients with IgA deficiency and celiac disease, Ig{{c1::G}} antibodies against endomysium, tTG, or gliadin are useful for diagnosis
Celiac disease is characterized histologically by {{c1::flattening}} of {{c2::villi}}
normal above, celiac below

Celiac disease is characterized histologically by increased 
intraepithelial {{c1::lymphocytes}}
normal above, celiac below
Celiac disease is associated with increased risk for small bowel carcinoma and {{c1::T-cell}} lymphoma
presents as refractory disease despite good dietary control; T-cell lymphoma = enteropathy associated T-cell lymphoma (EATL)

What is the treatment for celiac disease? 

{{c1::Gluten-free diet}}
{{c1::Tropical sprue}} presents similarly to celiac disease but responds to {{c2::antibiotics}}
{{c2::Crohn disease}} (IBD) is Th{{c1::1}} mediated
Cytokines released from TH1 and TH17 cells result in increased permeability of the GI tract to microbes and promote influx of neutrophils.
The crypts of Lieberkühn contain {{c1::Paneth}} cells, which secrete defensins, lysozyme, and TNF
involved in regulation of intestinal bacteria and may protect adjacent stem cells
Peyer patches are unencapsulated lymphoid tissue found in the {{c1::lamina propria}} and {{c1::submucosa}} of the {{c2::ileum}}
Peyer patches contain specialized {{c1::M cells}} that sample and present antigens to immune cells
B cells stimulated in germinal centers of Peyer patches differentiate into {{c1::IgA}}-secreting plasma cells, which reside in the lamina propria
IgA receives a protective secretory component and is then transported across the epithelium to the gut to deal with intraluminal antigen

Which immunoglobulin isotypes are expressed by mature, naive B-cells?

{{c1::IgM and IgD}}

Normally very few, if any, B cells leave the bone marrow until both sIgM and sIgD are present. Once both IgM and IgD are expressed, these cells are considered “transitional B cells” and require further stimuli through BAFF (B-cell activating factor receptor) in the peripheral lymphoid organs to fully develop into mature B cells. Once they leave the bone marrow, they populate peripheral lymphatic tissue. At this point both sIgM and sIgD act as antigen receptors.

Which primary lymphoid organ is the site of B-cell maturation? 

{{c1::Bone marrow}}
The {{c1::progenitor}} B cell lacks cytoplasmic μ and surface IgM/IgD
The {{c1::immature}} B cell is characterized by surface IgM, but no surface IgD
{{c1::Plasma}} cells are mature, differentiated B cells characterized by cytoplasmic Ig
B-cells with self-reactivity in the bone marrow to {{c2::particulate or cellular}} antigens are destroyed by clonal {{c1::deletion}}

Which class of helper T cell recruits eosinophils for parasite defense?

{{c1::Th2}}

Which class of helper T cell promotes IgE production by B cells?

{{c1::Th2}}

Which class of helper T cell secretes IFN-γ and IL-2? 

{{c1::Th1}}
Th1 cells secrete {{c1::IFN-γ}} and {{c2::IL-2}}

Is humoral immunity primarily mediated by B-cells or T-cells?

{{c1::B-cells}}
however, B cells require Th2 cells for an effective response
B-cell activation begins with presentation of foreign antigen on {{c1::MHC II}}, which is recognized by a T-cell receptor
B-cell activation requires a costimulatory signal from binding between the {{c1::CD40 receptor}} (B cell) and {{c1::CD40 ligand}} (Th2 cell)
the Th2 cell then secretes cytokines to induce Ig class switching; CD40 ligand is also known as CD154
Generation of antibody specificity occurs via {{c1::somatic hypermutation}} with {{c2::affinity maturation}}
random point mutations in the Fab region are selected for by clonal selection
Class switching of IgM is mediated by CD40L and cytokines from {{c1::Th2}} cells
isotype switch to either IgG, IgA, or IgE
Class switching to Ig{{c2::E}} is promoted by {{c1::IL-4::cytokine}} and {{c1::IL-13::cytokine}}

class switching to IgG is also promoted by IL-4

There is strong evidencethat IL-13 (which shares a receptor and subsequent signaling pathways with IL-4) can mediate allergic asthma responses in the absence of IL-4 activity

Is cell-mediated immunity primarily mediated by B-cells or T-cells?

{{c1::T-cells}}
{{c2::Natural killer}} cells are induced to kill cells that have an absence of {{c1::MHC I}} on their cell surface
or when exposed to a non-specific activation signal on target cells
{{c1::Superantigens}} are antigens that {{c2::cross-link}} the β region of T-cell receptors to MHC II on APCs outside the normal peptide-binding groove
results in loss of specificity with overactivation of T-cells, responsible for toxic shock syndrome
{{c1::Superantigens}} can activate any CD4+ T-cell, resulting in massive release of cytokines
{{c1::Anergy}} refers to a state in which an immune cell cannot become activated by exposure to its antigen
T-cells and B-cells become {{c1::anergic}} when exposed to their antigen without a costimulatory signal
mechanism of self-tolerance
Consumption of IgA in breast milk is an example of {{c1::passive}} immunization

Toxins that require passive immunity in exposed, unvaccinated patients may be remembered with the mnemonic "To Be Healed Very Rapidly": 

T: {{c1::Tetanus toxin}}
B: {{c2::Botulinum toxin}}
H: {{c3::HBV}}
V: {{c4::Varicella}}
R: {{c5::Rabies virus}}
also diphtheria antitoxin; combined active and passive immunizations can be given for hepatitis B and rabies exposure

Which type of vaccine induces a strong, often lifelong immunity? 

{{c1::Live, attenuated vaccines}}
comprised of live organisms which lose pathogenicity but retain capacity for transient growth within the inoculated host

Which type of vaccine has the potential to revert to a virulent form? 

{{c1::Live, attenuated vaccines}}
Live attenuated vaccines are often contraindicated in {{c1::pregnancy}} and {{c2::immunodeficiency}}
due to potential to cause significant disease

Do live attenuated vaccines induce cellular or humoral responses?

{{c1::Both cellular and humoral :)}}

What type of vaccine is the MMR vaccine? 

{{c1::Live attenuated}}
measles, mumps, rubella

What type of vaccine is the rotavirus vaccine? 

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the yellow fever vaccine? 

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the varicella vaccine? 

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the BCG vaccine? 

{{c1::Live attenuated}}

What type of vaccine is the intranasal influenza vaccine? 

{{c1::Live attenuated}}
The polio vaccine is a {{c1::live attenuated (oral) vaccine}}
Thus patients taking this will have higher mucosal immunity (luminal sIgA) vs patients taking the Salk vaccine

Which type of vaccine is a pathogen that has been inactivated by heat or chemicals? 

{{c1::Inactivated/killed vaccine}}

What is an advantage of inactivated vaccines compared to live attenuated? 

{{c1::Inactivated vaccines are safer}}

Which types of vaccine induce a relatively weak immune response? 

{{c1::Inactivated/killed vaccines}} and {{c1::Subunit vaccine}}

What type of vaccine is the rabies vaccine? 

{{c1::Inactivated/killed}}
RIP Always (Rabies, Influenza injection, Polio salk, hep A)

What type of vaccine is the injected influenza vaccine? 

{{c1::Inactivated/killed}}

This form of the influenza vaccine works by inducing neutralizing antibodies against the hemagglutinin antigen in selected viral strains; subsequent exposure of influenza virus results in antibodies inhibiting binding to sialylated receptors on the host cell membrane

RIP Always (Rabies, Influenza injection, Polio salk, hep A)

What type of vaccine is the hepatitis A vaccine? 

{{c1::Inactivated/killed}}
RIP Always (Rabies, Influenza injection, Polio salk, hep A)

What is the only useful immunoglobulin for diagnosing neonatal infections? 

{{c1::IgM}}

cannot use IgG because maternal IgG persists for up to one year 

certain subclasses of IgG that do not cross the placenta, and sometimes IgA is used for this purpose

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by cross-linking IgE on presensitized mast cells and basophils? 

{{c1::Type I HSR}}
Type I HSR occurs due to cross-linking of Ig{{c1::E}} on presensitized {{c3::mast cells}} and {{c3::basophils}} by antigen

This aggregates the FceRI (high afffinity) receptors on the mast cell, leading to the activation of non receptor tyrosine kinases and down stream effects (degranulation)

half-life of IgE is greatly extended when bound to the high affinity receptor on mast cells - FcRI.
The delayed response of mast cell and basophil activation involves production of {{c2::chemokines}} (ex. to attract eosinophils) and cytokines (particularly {{c1::leukotrienes}})
allows for maintenance of the acute inflammatory response and results in inflammation / tissue damage

Which type of hypersensitivity mediates anaphylaxis (e.g. food, drug, or bee sting allergies)?

{{c1::Type I}}

Which type of hypersensitivity mediates atopic reactions (e.g. asthma, allergic rhinitis)?

{{c1::Type I}}

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by binding of antibodies to cell-surface antigens? 

{{c1::Type II HSR}}
This can either result in <u>cell destruction</u>, <u>inflammation</u>, or <u>cellular dysfunction</u>
Type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular destruction by {{c1::opsonizing}} the target with antibodies

- Ex. autoimmune hemolytic anemia, ITP, transfusion reactions, hemolytic disease of the newborn

- Can lead to Phagocytosis or MAC mediated destruction, or NK antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicty
type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing cellular dysfunction, causing abnormal {{c1::blockade}} or {{c1::activation/inactivation}} of downstream cellular processes

Ex. Myasthenia gravis, Graves disease, Pemphigus vulgaris

In pemphigus vulgaris, autoantibodies against desmoglein-1 (αDsg1) / -3 (αDsg3) inactivate these proteins, resulting in loss of cell-cell adhesion
type II HSRs can cause pathology by inducing {{c1::inflammation}} by antibodies depositing on cell surfaces

Ex. goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever, hyperacute transplant rejection, bullous pemphigoid

- Leads to generation of C3a/C5a to attract neutrophils and other proinflammatory cells; or initiates Fc receptor-mediated inflammation

In bullous pemphigoid,  autoantibodies bind BP180, stimulating complement mediated inflammation and destruction of BP180 by recruitment of neutrophils

Which immunoglobulins mediate type II hypersensivity reactions? 

{{c1::IgM and IgG}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction are hemolytic disease of the newborn and transfusion reactions? 

{{c1::Type II HSR (cellular destruction)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is rheumatic fever? 

{{c1::Type II HSR (inflammation)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is hyperacute transplant rejection? 

{{c1::Type II HSR (inflammation)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is Graves disease and Myasthenia Gravis? 

{{c1::Type II HSR (cellular dysfunction)}}

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is characterized by circulating immune complexes? 

{{c1::Type III HSR}}
commonly associated with vasculitis and systemic manifestations
In type III HSRs, antigen-antibody complexes activate {{c1::complement}}, which attracts {{c2::neutrophils}}
neutrophils then release lysosomal enzymes
{{c1::Serum sickness}} is an immune complex disease in which antibodies to foreign serum proteins are produced
immune complexes form and are deposited in blood vessels, glomeruli, joint fluid, where they fix complement and cause skin petechiae, glomerulonephritis, and arthralgias, respectively,
Serum sickness presents with fever, urticaria, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy {{c1::1}} - {{c1::2}} weeks after antigen exposure

These patients have low serum C3 and C4 levels

The syndrome can occur without prior sensitization when relatively large amounts of antigen are given.

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is serum sickness? 

{{c1::Type III HSR}}
{{c1::Arthus reaction}} is a local subacute antibody-mediated HSR to antigen in intradermal injection
occurs in pre-sensitized individuals (has circulating IgG)
Arthus reaction leads to immune complex formation in the {{c1::skin}}; characterized by edema, necrosis, and activation of complement
Production of C5a and C3a lead to increased capillary permeability leading to edema. C5a attracts neutrophils to site

What type of hypersensivitity reaction is the Arthus reaction? 

{{c1::Type III HSR}}
caused by antigen-antibody complexes

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is polyarteritis nodosa? 

{{c1::Type III}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)? 

{{c1::Type III}}

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is T-cell mediated? 

{{c1::Type IV}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is type I diabetes mellitus? 

{{c1::Type IV HSR (direct cell cytotoxicity)}}

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is contact dermatitis (e.g. poison ivy, nickel allergy)? 

{{c1::Type IV HSR (CD4 & CD8 Mediated)}}

Poison ivy produces urushiol, which covalently binds to proteins on keratinocytes
- in the sensitization phase - langerhans cells uptake haptens (random skin proteins covalently bind urushiol) , travel to draining lymph nodes and interact with CD4+ / CD8 T cells (takes 10-14 days)
- following sensitization / re-exposure to urushiol, the hapten is taken up by skin cells (ex keratinocytes), which are targeted by CD8 CTLs

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is tuberculin skin test (PPD)? 

{{c1::Type IV HSR (CD8 Mediated)}}
This is to determine tuberculosis infection status

Which type(s) of hypersensitivity reactions are antibody-mediated? 

{{c1::I, II, and III}}
Arachidonic acids are converted to leukotrienes via the enzyme {{c1::5-lipooxygenase}}

Which leukotriene attracts and activates neutrophils?

{{c1::Leukotriene B4}}

Which leukotrienes mediate vasoconstriction, bronchospasm, and increased vascular permeability? 

{{c1::Leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4}}
essentially causes contraction: contraction of endothelial smooth muscle, bronchial smooth muscle, and pericytes
In general, leukotrienes cause vaso-{{c1::constriction}}
In general, leukotrienes cause {{c1::increased}} vascular permeability
Mast cells may be activated by cross-linking of cell-surface {{c1::IgE}} by antigen

What type of vaccine should be avoided in patients with SCID?

{{c1::Live vaccines}}

What is the most common primary immunodeficiency? 

{{c1::Selective IgA deficiency}}
Patients with {{c1::IgA deficiency}} may develop {{c2::anaphylaxis}} to IgA-containing products (e.g. blood transfusions, gammaglobulins)

What type of hypersensitivity reaction is SLE? 

{{c1::Type III* HSR (immune complex deposition)}}
*Exception: the hematologic complications (e.g. anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia) that occurs with lupus is a type II hpyersensitivity reaction

What HLA subtypes are associated with celiac disease? 

{{c1::DQ2}} and {{c1::DQ8}}
{{c1::Contact}} dermatitis presents with a pruritic, oozing rash with vesicles and edema due to a type {{c2::IV}} HSR
{{c1::Contact}} dermatitis arises upon exposure to allergens (e.g. nickel, poison ivy, neomycin)
lesions arise at the site of contact

What is the precursor molecule to prostanoids and leukotrienes?

{{c1::Arachidonic acid}}

First Aid Pharmacology: Immunology

Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against {{c1::α4-integrin}} used to treat {{c2::Multiple Sclerosis}} and {{c3::Crohn disease}}
α4-integrin is responsible for WBC adhesion

Which immune cell(s) secretes IFN-γ?

{{c1::NK cells and Th1 cells}}

Which cytokine increases MHC expression and antigen presentation on all cells?

{{c1::IFN-γ}}

Which interleukin is primarily responsible for stimulating IgE production?

{{c1::IL-4}}

Important in Type I HSR

IL-5 also plays a role
{{c1::Interferon-α}} and {{c1::-β}} are glycoproteins synthesized by virus-infected cells that act locally on uninfected cells, "priming" them for viral defense
Aka type I interferons, help local cells by degrading viral nucleic acid and protein

What type of hypersensitivity is allergic transfusion reaction?

{{c1::Type I HSR}}
Make sure patients with Selective IgA deficiency do not receive any transfused product with IgA in it

A febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction can exhibit what type of hypersensitivity reaction?

{{c1::Type II HSR}}
This is against donor HLA antigens and WBCs; however febrile nonhemolyic transfusion reactions can cause occur due to cytokines that accumulate during storage of blood products

What type of hypersensitivity is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction?

{{c1::Type II HSR}}

Which Rh type is the universal recipient of RBCs?

{{c1::Rh+}}
The BCG vaccine is primarily used to prevent {{c1::Tuberculosis}}, as well as an alternative treatment for {{c2::superficial bladder}} cancer
BCG works for Bladder Cancer by stimulating a <u>local immune response</u>
Trastuzumab is indicated for {{c1::Her2}}-positive cancers, the most important example being {{c2::breast}} cancer
Other uses include Her2+ Adenocarcinomas (ovarian, gastric, and lung / salivary glands)
Rituximab targets B cells by binding {{c1::CD20}} surface antigen

This is found on the surface of all B cells, normal and malignant

initiates complement fixation and ADCC, resulting in B cell depletion
s
Serum Sickness can be treated with pulsed {{c1::corticosteroid}} therapy

Symptoms include: Fever, Rash, Arthalgias, Proteinurea, Lymphadenopathy

Can also be treated with NSAIDS and antihistamines
In the treatment of Crohn's Disease, Natalizumab works by preventing adhesion of autoreactive gut homing {{c1::Th17}} cells
a4b7 integrin binds to MadCAM-1 found on mucosal endothelial cells
{{c1::Palivizumab}} is indicated for RSV prophylaxis in high-risk infants, and works by binding RSV {{c2::Fusion}} protein
The BCG vaccine is a {{c1::live attenuated}} or a live heterologous vaccine
Rituximab and Cetuximab are {{c1::Chimeric}} monoclonal antibodies
This is notable because people who take chimeric biologics are at risk of serum sickness
Rituximab is indicated for disorders of {{c1::B}} lymphocytes
Ex. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, B Cell Nonhodgkin Lymphoma, Rheumatoid Arthritis, certain Vasculitides, Refractory ITP
Type I interferons (IFN-a/IFN-B) work by {{c1::presensitizing}} cells to the products of viral {{c2::replication}}

Induces enzymes that degrade mRNA (RNAse L) and cellular factors associated with protein synthesis/cell cycle progression (Protein Kinase R - inactivates eIF-2) upon recognition of viral dsRNA

eIF-2  = eukaryotic translation Initiation Factor, which promotes the binding of the initiatory tRNA (met-tRNA) to the 40S Ribosomal subunits
Upon cytosolic recognition of viral {{c1::dsRNA}}, enzymes upregulated by IFN-a/B presensitization lead to apoptosis of the virus infected cell
IFN-Y is primarily produced by {{c1::TH1}} cells and primarily activates {{c2::Macrophages}} and {{c2::NK}} cells, along with CD8 CTLs

- Notably, Macrophages produce IL-12 in response which stimulates TH1 differentiation and proliferation as well as stimulating NK cells

- In sum, stimulation of NK cells results in reciprocal stimulation of other NK cells
IFN-y upregulates production of inducible {{c2::nitric oxide synthase (iNOS)}} which is involved in the generation of ONOO- (a powerful free radical)
IFN-y {{c1::activates}} cytotoxic T cells
This causes them to upregulate their "killing activity" so that on stimulus they will "inject" perforin and "release" Granzyme B to initiate apoptosis of target cells
IFN-y {{c1::stimulates}} NK cells and NKT cells
IFN-y is also produced by NK cells
Rh- mothers must be treated during pregnancy with {{c1::anti-D}} Immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) to prevent {{c2::anti-D}} IgG formation

- This opsonizes the D+ RBCs the mom has been exposed to, and results in rapid macrophage clearance before the mom can generate an immune response

- This is done during the third trimester period (week 28) if fetus tests + for Rh; Otherwise, subsequent pregnancies will result in Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn

While it is a very rare event for a woman to be Rh-sensitized prior to delivery, it does occasionally happen. Therefore, RhoGam may also be administered prenatally to prevent these rare circumstances. Smaller injections (MicrRhoGam 50 g) may be used during pregnancy at about the 28th week and can cut the incidence of Rh sensitization to about 0.7%.

During the immediate / early postpartum period after delivering an Rh+ fetus, must Rh- mothers be given anti-D Ig?

{{c1::yes}}
This is because the mother may have been exposed to D+ RBCs during the delivery process
Hemolytic disease of the newborn is also known as {{c1::Erythroblastosis fetalis}}

- This occurs when a blood group mismatch (Ex. ABO, Rh, Kell) between the mother and the fetus results in antibodies crossing the placental circulation resulting in destruction of fetal RBCs

- In terms of incompatibility severity (Rh > Kell > ABO)

- Kell antigen system is polymorphic transmembrane glycoprotein that can be used as a blood grouping system; defective in McLeod Syndrome (neuroacanthocystosis)
Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn has the potential to occur when a Rh{{c1::-}} mother has a Rh{{c1::+}} fetus
- Because the Rh- mother has not developed immune tolerance to the D antigen, exposure can cause immune sensitization to D antigen

Assuming RhoGam is not given, the first time a mother is Rh- and delivers a Rh+ fetus, the mother will form what substance?

{{c1::}}

- Exposure to fetal blood (often during delivery) results in the formation of maternal anti-D IgG

- Subsquent pregnancies with Rh+ babies will be affected as anti-D IgG can cross the placenta
If an Rh- mother with anti-D IgG antibodies has a subsequent pregnancy with an Rh+ fetus, the fetus can develop {{c1::erythroblastosis fetalis}}

- This is caused when RBC destruction in fetus results in mass fluid accumulation, which can lead to miscarraige and fetal death

- the massive hemolytic anemia causes a high output heart failure which quickly becomes congestive, as well as stimulates high levels of extramedullary hematopoesis which obstruct the portal vein (portal HTN) >> edema

If an Rh- mother with anti-D IgG antibodies has a subsequent pregnancy with an Rh+ fetus and the baby survives to delivery, the newborn can develop {{c1::Jaundice}}; which in serious cases can also manifest with {{c2::Kernicterus}}

- This is due to the autoimmune destruction of RBCs leading to lots of bilirubin being formed

- bile acids can deposit in the basal ganglia, causing kernicterus

{{c1::Killed/inactivated vaccine}} and {{c1::Subunit Vaccine }}

A phagocyte’s cytoplasm does not flow easily over {{c1::hydrophilic substances}} such as those found on other bacteria that produce {{c2::polysaccharide capsules}}, e.g. {{c3::Streptococcus pneumoniae}}.

Production of capsules that are anti-phagocytic is a major determinant of many pathogens' ability to cause disease. This is why antibody against bacterial capsules can often serve to protect a patient from capsule producing bacteria - it greatly enhances phagocytosis that would normally be impaired by the presence of the capsule.
{{c1::Defensins}} and {{c2::protegrins}} are small polypeptides that disrupt membrane function of many pathogens and are commonly found inside lysosomes
Lysosomes typically fuse with phagosomes

As the population of {{c2::CD34+ HSC::cell type}} expands in the bone marrow and some will receive signals to progress to a {{c1::pro-B cell}}. This process is assisted by interaction with {{c3::bone marrow stromal cells}}.
Bone marrow {{c1::stromal cells}} secrete {{c2::IL-7}} and {{c3::IL-3 }} which drive and support development of {{c4:: progenitor B cells }}
B-cell differentiation starts from {{c1::6 months}} gestational age and continues {{c2::through life}}
{{c2::Progenitor B cells}} rearrange their immunoglobulin genes for the {{c1::variable heavy chain regions::region of Ab}}

Determination of antigen specificity occurs very early in B cell development when genes for the variable regions of the Ig molecule rearrange. Once the variable regions are determined, antigen specificity is maintained throughout the development of that B cell and for each of its progeny (clones).
The {{c1::pre-B cell}} is defined by the expression of  {{c2::rearranged Ig heavy chain}} and {{c3::the initiation of light chain rearrangement. }}
{{c2::Rearranged heavy chain}} is "tested" by associating with a {{c3::surrogate light chain}} in {{c1::Pre-B-cells::cell type}}
If the heavy chain can not associate with the surrogate light chain, it will {{c1::not transit to the cell surface}} and the pre-B cell {{c2::fails this checkpoint}}.

If the surrogate light chain and heavy chain get to {{c1::the surface of the cell}}, the pre-B cell will be signaled that the {{c2::heavy chain is functional}} and {{c3::allelic exclusion}} will be achieved.

Allelic exclusion is the phenomenon that even though a B cell genetically encodes for two heavy chains or light chains, only one of the loci will be expressed

-Assuming that that the alleles that are expressed are the surrogate light chain and the variable heavy chain that transitions to the surface
{{c1::Immature B-cells}} express only surface {{c2::IgM}} which functions as the {{c3::antigen receptor for the B cell  }}
{{c1::Immature B cells}} will become "tolerant" to {{c2::soluable self antigen}} through a process known as {{c3::clonal anergy}}.
In other words, the B cell will be sent signals which make it unable to respond to that antigen when it encounters it in the future
To transmit signals to the cell, B-cell surface Ig associates with two transmembrane molecules, {{c1::Ig-alpha}} and {{c1::Ig-beta}}, to form the {{c3::B cell receptor.}}

The antigen receptor on the surface of the B cells have the Fab portions project into the extracellular environment and the Fc portions are embedded in the cell membrane (see diagram above). Surface Ig has a very short cytoplasmic tail.
B cells that do not come into contact with the antigen that their surface Ig is specific for during circulation will {{c1::die by neglect}}
many B cells will be produced that never become activated and die within a few weeks

B cells that find the antigen that their surface Ig is specific for will become activated to proliferate and produce antibody against that antigen. This scenario is called the {{c1::CLONAL SELECTION}} theory
{{c1::Thymus-independent antigens (T-independent Ags or TI Ags)}} can activate B cells without {{c2::the assistance of T lymphocyte}}
In a {{c1::Type I T-independent}} response, antigen molecules activate the B cell by stimulating a {{c2::receptor OTHER than the B cell receptor.}}
Type I T-independent Ag result in a {{c1::polyclonal::type of activation}} activation of B cells

Because Type I TI antigens activate B cells with different specificities to produce antibody, antibodies with a myriad of specificities are produced in response to type I TI antigens (heterophile antibodies).
Example of Type I T indpendent antigens include{{c1:: Bacterial LPS}} and {{c2::Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)}}
LPS and EBV are considered B cell mitogens because they activate multiple B-cell lineages (polyclonal activation)
B cells whose key function is to respond to {{c5::Type II T-independent antigens}} are called the {{c2::marginal zone B cells}} and they are found in the {{c3::spleen}} and in the {{c4::lymph node}}
Marginal zone B cells tend to be long-lived and do not circulate and serve as an important first responding cell to encapsulated bacteria and viruses.
Type II T-independent antigen binds {{c1::directly with surface Ig}}, cross-linking numerous surface molecules on the B cell.
{{c1::Cross-linked B-cell IgM receptors}} cluster and move to one area or "pole" of the cell in a process known as {{c2::capping}} that results in B-cell activation
Capping requires reaction of a threshold number of epitopes with Ab on the cell surface
In any {{c1::type II T-independent Ab}} response, {{c2::IgM}} is the only class of Ab synthesized by the B-cell
Synthesis of IgM can continue for prolonged periods of time if the antigen persists within the host, but slowly comes to a halt when the Ag is cleared from the system
On a {{c1::second}} encounter with a T-independent Ag, there is {{c2::no memory response}}
– it is identical to the primary response
Children under {{c1::2 yrs}} of age respond {{c2::poorly/not respond}} to {{c4::type II T-ind Ag}} due to the lack of {{c3::fully developed marginal zone B cell population}}
{{c2::Type II T independent Ag}} may become {{c1::T dependent}} if conjugated to a {{c1::T dependent antigen}}
(e.g. a protein).
The first step of T-{{c1::dependent}} response is the activation of T cells in the context of {{c2::HLA class II}}
In the {{c1::T-dependent}} response B cell binds Ag through the {{c3::BCR}} and presents Ag through {{c2::HLA Class II}}

In the {{c1::T dependent}} response an activated Th cell will interact with the B cell specific for {{c3::the same antigen}} through {{c2::HLA class II}} (B cell)/TCR (T cell) and costimulatory molecules
In T-dependent response the activated T cell provides {{c1::cytokines and cell:cell interactions}} to promote development of {{c2::plasma cells}} and  {{c3::memory B cells}}
Once activated by the HLA-II molecule on the surface of the B-cell

During a {{c3::T dependent response}}, {{c2::IgM}} is the {{c1::first}} Ab secreted (similar to T ind. response) but when a B-cell interacts with a T-cell, the T cell and its cytokines induce an {{c4::isotype switch
(or “class switch”)}}

B cells also need two signals to become fully activated:
1) {{c1::CD40 (B cell): CD40L (activated Th cell)}}
2) {{c2::CK receptors (B cell): Cytokines (activated Th cell)}}
Isotype switching in T-dependent response is {{c1::sequential (M -> G or M -> G ->  A)}} or {{c2::direct (M -> A)}} and it is {{c3::irreversible}}

Irreversible due to excision and deletion of heavy chain gene isotypes in front of the Ig gene expressed.

It is important to remember that even though the isotype switches, the antigen specificity remains unchanged. Thus, a single B cell may express thousands of Abs on its cell surface, and the isotype of these Abs may change over the life of the B cell, but the Ab specificity does not.
A {{c1::plasma cell}} is a terminally differentiated B cell whose sole purpose is the {{c2::secretion of antibody}}
This fully activated B cell quickly spends itself metabolically and dies. Plasma cell half lives are measured in days.

The {{c1::memory cell}} lasts for many years and is capable of rapidly responding to antigen. Its progeny become a {{c2::plasma cell}} or another {{c3::memory cell}} upon a second encounter with the antigen.
This is due to, among other things, the fact that the isotype switch has already occurred and that it is at a higher activation state than a mature but naïve B cell.
Memory cells can be stimulated with {{c1::smaller}} amounts of antigen than "naive" B cells.

The net result of the primary antibody response to a Tdependent antigen is an increase in the number of clones pre committed to responding to the antigen and a concomitant switch in isotype for the majority of the respo nding B cells. This enables the system to respond much more rapidly and with greater intensity upon a second exposure to the antigen. We capitalize on this phenomenon every time we give or receive an immunization.
The {{c3::lag phase}} of a primary immune response is characterized by {{c1::B cell clonal selection}} based on pre-programmed antigen specificity, this phase lasts {{c2::7-10 days }}
{{c3::Log}} phase of primary immune response is characterized by {{c1::exponential increase of antibody levels}}. {{c2::IgM}} is always the isotype produced first in the primary response
The Secondary response {{c1::Lag}} phase is shorter, typically {{c2::1-3 days }}

This is observed because of: (1) increased numbers of precursors; (2) isotype switching has already occurred; (3) higher affinity antigen receptors are present; and (4) the memory cells are at a higher activation state or level.
The secondary immune response is greater in {{c1::length of time}} and magnitude of {{c2::antibodies produced}}.
IgG is the predominant ab produced and it has a half life of 20 something days
{{c1::IgG}} is the predominant isotype in a secondary immune response
However, depending on the nature and presentation of the antigen, IgA or IgE may be produced. Levels of antibody produced are much higher than in the primary response.

A {{c2::hapten }}must be chemically conjugated to a {{c1::protein}} or {{c1::some other T-dependent antigen}} in order for sufficient {{c3::BCRs}} to be engaged to create a {{c4::T-dependent}} immune response

haptens are not peptides and cannot be loaded into HLA. Therefore, the protein not only concentrates the hapten but also serves as a protein that can be broken down into peptides to be presented in HLA II. The T cells respond to the protein (Discussed in the T cell lectures) and simultaneously provide the help needed by the B cells to make antibody against the hapten.

An example of hapten-carrier phenomenon is sensitization to penicillin. Penicillin alone is not immunogenic. However, if it becomes associated with some tissue or serum proteins, it will induce antibody production that results in the sensitization

If a {{c1::type II T-independent}} antigen (that is recognized by surface Ig) is chemically conjugated to a {{c2::protein (a T-dependent antigen}}), the response to the antigen will become {{c3::T-dependent.}}

A practical example of this is the Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine. This vaccine was initially composed solely of capsular polysaccharide (a carbohydrate polymer and T-independent Ag). However, the immune response to this was poor in children under the age of two, and this is a time of great susceptibility to meningitis caused by this organism. In later formulations, it was conjugated to a protein immunogen and children as young as two months of age were found to produce a good antibody response when immunized with this formulation. Another conjugated vaccine is the more recently licensed pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
levels of maternal {{c1::IgG}} in the infant's circulation peak at {{c2::parturition}}. After {{c2::parturition}}, they {{c3::slowly decline.}}

Significant protection is provided by maternal IgG for up to 6 months after birth. At this time, the infant's B cells are beginning to produce significant quantities of antibody. However, because adult levels of immunoglobulins are not attained for several years, many consider infants and small children as developmentally immunocompromised. The infant’s normal gut flora is responsible for stimulating antibodies (called “natural” antibodies) which serve to protect them from certain pathogens. It is well known that children are not fully colonized in their gut until later in early childhood – thus delaying the presence of the natural antibodies.
T cell-derived {{c1::cytokines}} induce an {{c2::isotype switch}} to either a subclass of {{c3::IgG}}, {{c3::IgA}}, or {{c3::IgE}} in B cells

{{c1::CD40L}} that is transiently expressed on the surface of {{c2::activated T cells}} binds to {{c3::CD40}} receptor on the {{c4::activated B cell}} and causes differentiate to {{c5::plasma}} or {{c5::memory cells }}
In a {{c2::Type II T-independent}} response the antigen reacts {{c1::directly with the surface Ig}}, cross-linking numerous surface molecules on the B cell.

Inflammation can destroy the barrier that keeps the microorganisms out
{{c1::Immune cells in the mucosal epithelium (IELs)}} in the GI are mostly {{c2::CD8+ T cells }}
They are often scattered and are in a higher activation state
Outer layer of mucus secreted by Goblet cells in the GI houses {{c1::commensal bacteria}}. The Inner layer of mucus contains {{c2::anti microbial peptides (AMPs)}} & {{c3::IgA}}

{{c5::Intraepithelial lymphocytes}} are

{{c1::M cells}} are positioned {{c2::directly over B cell follicles}} and transport {{c3::antigens and microorganisms}} through {{c4::transcytosis}} from gut lumen into lymphoid tissue
{{c1::B cell follicles}} are randomly placed underneath the {{c2::epithelial layer }} of the {{c3::small and large intestine }}
{{c1::Nod Like Receptors}} and {{c1::Toll Like Receptors}} in the mucosal immunity system are on the {{c2::basolateral membrane}} of the epithelial cells
This prevents an immune response from occuring by PAMPs that are in the lumen of the GI

TLR signaling in the GI tract results in five main functions:

v. {{c5::Increase phagocytic ability of dendritic cells and macrophages without promoting inflammation }}

NLR signaling (eg, NOD2) within cells of the GI tract results in two main functions:

2) {{c2::Inhibit the production of proinflammatory cytokines. }}

The majority of the activated circulating adaptive immune cells in the GI are:
1) {{c1::CD4+ T cells in the lamina propria}}
2) {{c2::CD8+ T cells as IELs with in the epithelial cell barrier}}
3) {{c3::Effector B cells (including plasma cells) in the peyers patches }}

Antigens cross the intestinal mucosa and are presented to secondary lymphatic tissues through

2) {{c2::Capture from the intestinal lumen by dendrtic cells }}
Dendritic cells extend projections between adjacent epithelial cells, without disrupting the tight junctions. They process and present the antigens to T-cells

In a {{c1::pathogenic}} state Dendritic cells of the GI mucosa produce {{c2::IL-6}} which promotes the differentiation of T-cells into {{c3::Th17 cells}}

TGF-beta + IL-6 = Th17 cells

IL-17 & IL-22 produced by TH17 cells induce neutrophil production & recruitment, induce epithelial cell production of antimicrobial peptides, and promote enhanced barrier functions.
During activation and proliferation of B cells in gastric mucosa, they differentiate into {{c1::IgA}}-secreting plasma cells due to the presence of {{c2::TGF-B. }}

In celiac disease, gliaden a promotes autoreactive activity of {{c1::intraepithelial (IE) CD8+ T cells}} by promoting secretion of {{c2::IL-15}}

T-dependent activation of gluten-specific and TG2-specific B cells to produce {{c1::anti-gliadin}} and {{c1::anti-TG2}} antibodies

Contributes to enhanced inflammation due to commensals

Particullarly in tight junctions
Changes in {{c1::microbiota}} are thought to cause {{c2::mucosal immune responses}} in {{c2::IBD}}
{{c1::Innate Sensor cells}} recognize PAMPS of the {{c2::respiratory system}} and produce {{c3::cytokines to direct an immune response}}
specifically type 1 cytokines
{{c1::Alveolar macrophages}} are typically turned off through cell:cell contact and cytokines from {{c2::alveolar epithelial cells}}
During pathogenesis, AECs die and lost homeostatic signals. Alveolar Mφ become activated
{{c1::Innate memory T cells}} and {{c1::NK cells}} in the respiratory epithelium are activated by {{c2::tier 1 cytokines}} secreted by {{c3::sensor cells. }}
Activated {{c1::T-cells}} and {{c1::NK cells}} of the respiratory epithelium secrete {{c2::tier 2 cytokines}} that recruit {{c3::effector cells }}

Effector cells = monocytes, neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, macrophages, and mast cells  

The cytokines produce will determine the type of effector cell response that is “tailored” to the invading pathogen. For example, if the invading pathogen is a virus, IFN-gamma will predominate as the Tier 2 cytokine, while if the invading pathogen is a helminth, IL-4, IL-5, and IL- 13 will predominate.
Antigens of some pathogens that are structurally similar to host tissues may cause an {{c1::autoimmune response}}
{{c1::Lysozymes}} are an innate soluable factors that {{c2::hydrolysis the cell wall peptidoglycan}}
{{c1::Cathelicidin}} is an innate soluable factor have rapid antimicrobial activity against a wide range of gram positive and gram negative pathogenic microbes, as well as viruses
{{c2::Obligate intracellular pathogens}} are {{c1::required to spend part or all of their life cycle in a host }}
{{c1::Facultative intracellular pathogens}} can spend part of their life cycle inside a host but are not required to
{{c1::Humoral Immunity}} combats extracellular Pathogens
{{c1::Cell mediated Immunity}} combats intracellular pathogens
The immune system can counter the production of the antiphagocytic capsule produced by bacteria by producing {{c1::opsonizing antibody directed against the capsule}}
When the opsonizing antibody is deposited along with complement C3b on the surface of an extracellular pathogen, uptake by phagocytes is greatly enhanced
A Neutralizing antibody inhibits {{c1::attachment of a pathogen to receptors on host tissue}}
At mucosal surfaces, IgA production is a major means that the host uses to defend against infections

Extracellular bacteria avoid the harsh environment of the circulatory system and/or within tissues by adhering to, colonizing, and infecting {{c1::only mucosal surfaces}} where {{c2::the amount of phagocytic cells and complement are very low}}.

Examples of this would be the bacteria that cause cholera, pertussis, and diphtheria. In each case, once the epithelium is colonized, they release a toxin (or toxins) that are absorbed through the mucosa and cause the actual disease

{{c1::Bacterial Endotoxins (LPS)}} 
1) are produced by {{c2::Gram neg bacteria }}
2) is composed of a {{c3::lipid core or backbone (called Lipid A)}} and {{c3::numerous carbohydrate side chains}}
3) Has great {{c4::variablility}} between strains
4) Is stable at {{c5::high temperatures }}
5) CANNOT be made into a {{c6::toxoid}}
6) Can act as an {{c7::exogenous pyrogen that in turns activate endogenous pyrogen}}

Because the composition and complexity of the carbohydrate side chains is highly variable from one Gram-negative bacterium to another, the antigenic structure of LPS is also highly variable from one Gram-negative bacterium to another. This means that it is unlikely that neutralizing antibodies resulting from one exposure to LPS will induce protective immunity against another LPS from a different Gram-negative bacterium.
LPS is an exogenous pyrogen that induces the sequential production of endogenous pyrogens: {{c1::IL-1}}, {{c2::TNF-alpha}}, and {{c3::IL-6}}

Bacterial Exotoxins 
1) Can be produced by either {{c1::Gram-negative or Gram-positive}}
2) has a {{c2::specific receptor}} on host cells that, when ligated by the toxin, causes {{c2::its pharmacological effects}}
3) produce disease at levels {{c3::less than will induce immunity}}.\
4) Can be made into {{c4::toxoids to generate protective immunity}}

Exotoxins require some degree of homology to function. THUS, exotoxins can be neutralized by specific Ab.

To induce protective antibody responses, the toxin (e.g., tetanus toxin) is grown in vitro in large quantities and is chemically or physically altered in such a manner as to yield it nontoxic (no longer binds its receptor) but still induces an antibody response (is immunogenic). The result is a toxoid that can be safely used to immunize against the toxin

{{c1::Toxic shock syndrome}} patients present with a sudden high fever, Low blood pressure (hypotension), Vomiting or diarrhea, A rash resembling a sunburn, particularly on your palms and soles, muscle aches, Redness of your eyes, mouth and throat
{{c1::Virulence Factors}} are substances produced by a pathogenic organism which enable it to cause disease in the host

E.g., capsules, toxins, attachment factors

In some cases, immune responses against the virulence factors induce protective immune responses. Virulence factors are, therefore, plausible vaccine targets in many instances.
{{c1::Obligate intracellular pathogens}} may activate a {{c2::Th2 helper response}} or become {{c3::latent}} inside the host cell in order to survive/ avoid an immune response
A Th2 response is ineffectual at eliminating intracellular infections because it is an antibody-dominated response and will serve to counter-regulate and suppress the more effective Th1 response.
Antibody may neutralize viral particles by binding to {{c1::viral receptors used to attach to host cells}}
{{c2::opsonizing antibodies}} for viruses can be detrimental to the host because they provide a vehicle for the virus to enter a host cell through {{c1::Fc receptor interaction}}
Complement can destroy enveloped viral particles by the {{c1::classical pathway.}}

Viruses can escape the immune response by 
1) Blocking {{c1::the activation pathways of IFNs}}
2) Blocking {{c2::HLA molecule expression or delivery of processed peptides to HLA molecules}}
3) Blocking {{c3::complement activation}}
4) {{c4::Mutating themselves in such a way that their antigenic composition constantly changes}}
5) Inducing {{c5::generalized immune suppression}} or {{c5::producing immune regulatory cytokine homologs}}
A hallmark of {{c1::helminthic parasite infections}} in humans is the increased levels of serum {{c2::IgE}} and {{c3::eosinophilia}}

Eosinophils degranulate upon encountering IgE bound to antigen and release substances such as histamines, vasoactive amines, chemotactic factors, and induce smooth muscle contraction. These factors have demonstrated toxic effects on most helminths
Strong {{c1::CD4+ Th1}} and {{c1::Th17}} cell responses correlate with protective immunity against {{c2::extracellular fungi}}

IFN-gamma produced by Th1 cells is critical for activating and increasing the phagocytic activity of phagocytes at the site of infection. IL-17 from Th17 cells recruits neutrophils to the site of invasion. Recently, Th17 cells are also implicated in the resolution/control of intracellular fungal infections, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii.
When {{c1::CD4+ T cell levels}} in patients infected with HIV drop, these patients are at an increased risk of life-threatening {{c2::fungal infections}}
Sepsis is defined as {{c1::life threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection}}

Sepsis can be induced by
1) {{c1::Gram-negative lipopolysaccharide}}
2) {{c2:: Gram-positive, peptidoglycan or teichoic acid}} 
3) {{c3::Gram-positive and Gram-negative f-met-leu-phe}} or {{c3::5’-mCPG}} 
4) {{c4::Bacterial and viral superantigens}}
{{c1::Atopy}} is the susceptibility of certain individuals to natural sensitization by environmental allergens, e.g., pollen, spores, foods.
Atopic serum: serum from a sensitized atopic individual that contains antibodies to an allergen.

The sensitization phase of Type I Hypersensitivity Reactions inclues:
1) {{c1::Exposure to allergen}}
2) {{c2::Th2 activation and IgE production}}
3) {{c3::IgE binds to mast cell Fc receptors}}

1) Some substances have a greater propensity to induce IgE production than others. Therefore, the nature of the allergen is important, e.g. environmental (molds, pollen and grasses), food (primarily milk, eggs, nuts, wheat, fish, and shellfish) insect venom allergies and certain drugs are all examples

2) Route of exposure to an allergen is important in inducing IgE production – with primary exposure of antigen to the respiratory and G.I. tracts and the skin being more stimulatory for IgE production. Mast cells and IgE-bearing B cells tend to line the skin, mucous membranes and connective tissue. Antigen processing cells in these regions tend to drive the initial immune response from Th0  to Th2 via the production of IL-4.

The activator phase of Type I Hypersensitivity reactions includes:
4. {{c1::2nd degree or subsequent re-exposure to allergen}}
5. binding of allergen to {{c2::cell-associated IgE}} and crosslinking of at least {{c2::two IgE Fc receptor}} molecules on the {{c2::mast cell}} surface
6. {{c3::signal transduction in mast cells and basophils}}
Route of exposure to an allergen is important in inducing {{c1::IgE}} production in {{c2::Type I}} HSRs

primary exposure of antigen to the respiratory and G.I. tracts and the skin being more stimulatory for IgE production. Mast cells and IgE-bearing B cells tend to line the skin, mucous membranes and connective tissue. Antigen processing cells in these regions tend to drive the initial immune response from Th0  to Th2 via the production of IL-4.
The very {{c1::young (mostly)}} and very {{c1::old (rarely}}) are most vulnerable to type I HSRs

The effector phase of Type I hypersensitivity reactions is characterized by: 
7. {{c1::mediator secretion, and}}
8. {{c2::mediator effects on end-organs such as blood vessels and bronchial smooth muscle}}
The {{c1::BCG}} vaccine shifts the overall immune response profile in an individual to {{c2::Th1}} thus improving response to {{c3::type I HSR }}
{{c1::gamma/delta TCR+}} and their recognition of nonpeptide antigens processed by {{c2::CD1}} molecules mediates the induction of {{c3::allergic asthma}}
Mild symptoms of {{c1::Type I}}  HSR are wheal and flare, nasal congestion, enlarged nasal turbinates with bluish-grey mucosa, and if ingested – vomiting and diarrhea
Severe symtpoms of {{c1::Type I HSR}} include laryngeal edema and severe anaphaxysis (hypotension and shock, bronchospasm, cardiac arrhythmia, cardiorespiratory arrest)

Labs that can be ordered for Type I HSRs are
1) {{c1::Skin tests to identify possible allergin }}
2) {{c2::RIST (total IgE)}} or {{c2::RAST (specific IgE)}}

It’s important to remember that when interpreting these two tests that they may yield low titers in a very atopic patient probably due to sequestration of IgE on high affinity mast cells (low levels free in serum) Alternatively, they may be suspiciously high in the serum of a non-atopic patient due to IgE not being sequestered on to mast cells or during parasitic infections.
{{c1::Antihistamines}} – which compete with histamine for receptor sites H1 or H2 can be used to treat {{c2::Type I HSR}}
{{c1::Cromolyn sodium}} – stabilizes {{c2::mast cell membranes}} preventing {{c2::degranulation}} when administered prior to exposure
Useful for preventing Type I HSR
{{c1::Corticosteroids}} – preventing the activation of {{c2::arachidonic acid}} pathways thus preventing {{c3::late phase reactants of Type I HSRs}}
{{c1::Epinephrine}} directly reverses the effects of {{c2::histamine}} on smooth muscle constriction in the g.i. and respiratory tracts and relaxation in the vasculature.
Useful in type I HSR
{{c1::Omalizumab}} inhibits the binding of {{c2::IgE}} to {{c2::FcεRI}} on the surface of mast cells and basophils
{{c1::Montelukast (Singulair)}} Blocks the action of {{c2::leukotriene D4}}

{{c1::Subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT}}) and {{c1::Sublingual immunotherapy (SLIT)}} are two forms of Allergen immunotherapy that are used for Type I HSR by promoting the switch from {{c1::Th2}} to {{c1::Th1}} mediated responses
{{c2::Type II hypersensitivity}} reactions INVOLVE {{c1::INSOLUBLE ANTIGEN (e.g. cells or tissue).}} with or without {{c1::complement activation}}
In 80% of all humans, A and B alloantigens are also present as mucopolysaccharides in {{c1::secretions such as saliva, sweat, etc}}. These people are known as {{c1::secretors}}
Human serum contains naturally occurring {{c2::IgM}} antibodies against A and B antigen called {{c1::isohemaglutinins}}

These are “natural” antibodies in that they occur without deliberate sensitization/immunization against them. It is a widely held belief that they are a result of the colonization of the human gut over time (in the first two to three years of life) with normal intestinal flora and that these microorganisms induce cross-reacting antibodies against ABO blood group antigens. In support of this hypothesis is the fact that newborns normally lack the naturally occurring anti-A and/or anti-B but acquire these over time coincident with colonization of the intestine
Unlike the ABO system, humans do not have naturally-occurring antibodies to {{c1::Rh antigens.}}

In erythroblastosis fatalis, {{c1::Rh+ RBCs}} of the infant induce {{c2::IgG anti-Rh antibodies}} in the mother. 

During a subsequent pregnancy, these antibodies cross the placenta, entering the fetal circulation where they {{c3::bind RBC and opsonization occurs}}

At or about the time of parturition there is a high degree of mixing of the maternal and fetal circulation

Prenatal Rh typing of both parents is required to verify Rh compatability

Symptoms of erythroblastosis fetalis are
1) {{c1::Anemia}}
2) {{c2::Ascities}} and {{c2::edema}}
3) {{c3::Hepatosplenomegaly}}
4) {{c4::Leukopenia}} and {{c4::thrombocytopenia}}

Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia as a result of erythroid hyperplasia in the bone
marrow. Bone marrow erythropoiesis occurs at such a high rate as to “crowd-out”
other bone marrow progenitors
In {{c2::Major incompatibility}} of blood transfusions the {{c1::recipient}} has antibodies against {{c1::donor}} RBCs
In {{c2::Minor incompatibility}} of blood transfusion the {{c1::donor}} has antibodies against {{c1::recipient}} RBCs

Non-hemolytic reactions of blood transfusions include
1) {{c1::Antibody to white blood cells}}
2) {{c2::IgE Anti-IgA  Abs (from individuals with IgA defeciency)}}
3) {{c3::Contamination of blood or blood products}}

In Arthus reaction, Activated neutrophils fail phagocytize the immune complexes and in a process known as “{{c1::frustrated phagocytosis}}, they release an array of {{c2::proteases}}, {{c2::collagenases}}, {{c2::reactive specie}}s which damage near by tissue
{{c1::Type IV hypersensitivity}} (a.k.a., {{c2::delayed-type hypersensitivity}}) reactions are {{c3::cell-mediated}} immune responses

These involve immune responses initiated primarily by antigen-specific CD4+ T helper cells. The memory T cells become effector T cells on second exposure to an antigen, releasing mediators and cytokines that attract and activate other mononuclear cells and macrophages
it takes {{c1::24-48}} hours for {{c3::Type IV HSR}} reactions to occur in a {{c2::sensitized}} individual.
The accumulation of cells and inflammatory factors leads to erythema at the site but the key manifestation is induration which is a cutaneous or subcutaneous hardening

Sensitization Stage of Type IV HSR involves 
a. {{c1::Subcutaneous antigen is processed by APC (Langerhans cell)}}
b. {{c2::Th cell recognition of HLA-peptide on APC and differentiation into Th1 cell}}

Elicitation stage of type IV HSRs involves 

1) {{c1::Subsequent antigen challenge activates specific Th1 cells}} who
produce cytokines (IFN g , MCP 1, and TNF a ) which activate
macrophages.

2) {{c2::Inflammatory cells (Macrophages) accumulate and result in local
tissue damage.}}
{{c2::Granulomatous hypersensitivity}} is a {{c3::Type IV HSR}} where the antigen is persistent resulting in a {{c1::chronic immune response.}}
For example, exposure to Schistosoma mansoni eggs.
{{c1::Herd immunity }} is the prevention of the transimission of a disease in a population because the majority of the population is immunized
The percentage of the population that needs to be immune to provide herd immunity is dependent on {{c1::attack rate}} of the infectious agent.
The {{c1::attack rate}} of an infectious agent is the number of individuals infected  out of the people who have been exposed to the pathogen

For example, measles virus is highly infectious, has a high attack rate (perhaps the highest known). To provide immunity to measles, a high rate of compliant immunization must be present in the population.

Examples of killed vaccines include 

1) {{c1::Inactivated trivalent influenza vaccine}}
2) {{c2::rabies}}
3) {{c3::hepatitis A (Havrix)}}
4) {{c4::intramuscular poliovirus (IPV) }}
5) {{c5::Japanese Encephalitis Virus }}
Pneumonic: Jhi-rip (Gee-rip)
Killed vaccines are not always affective because the immune system {{c1::may respond differently to a killed pathogen vs a live pathogen}}

Example: When first exploring vaccination, we learned that on occasion, persons receiving killed vaccines have actually contracted exacerbated disease when compared to those individuals that contract measles naturally. The initial measles vaccine was a killed vaccine and in a very small percentage of people immunized induced a severe exacerbated form of measles encephalitis upon exposure to wild type measles virus. We now use a live, attenuated measles vaccine in the MMR and this side effect no longer occurs.

Advantages of killed/inactivated vaccines:

1) {{c1::Stable at a variety of temperatures }}
2) Safe to use in {{c2::immune compromised patients}} and {{c2::pregnant women }}
Antibodies of the IgG class can cross the placenta and provide immunity in a child for the first 4-6 months of life.

Disadvantage of killed/inactivated genes:

1) {{c1::Weakly immunologic, requires multiple boosters }}
2) {{c2::Proccessed through the exogenous pathway, therefore can only mediate an HLA-II/Th2 response}}
{{c3::Live attenuated pathogens}} in vaccines lost their {{c1::disease- producing ability}} but retain the {{c2::ability to replicate}} within the host.

Examples of live attenuated vaccines (that aren't covered in first aid) are: 

5)  {{c5::tuberculosis vaccine - only used outside US}}
7)  {{c7::vaccinia virus vaccine for smallpox (also a heterologous vaccine)}}
10)  {{c10::Typhoid, can also be a polysacharide subunit vaccine}}
11)  {{c11::Cholera}}

Pneumonic: 

Cho-Typ, Tub-Vac

Disadvantages of Live attenuated vaccines include: 

1) {{c1::They require cold chain storage and transport}}
2) {{c2::Can revert to a virulent form}}
The smallpox vaccine is derived from a very closely related virus called the {{c1::vaccinia virus }} this is an example of {{c2::Live heterologous vaccines}}

There is enough antigenic similarity between smallpox and vaccinia that the vaccinia provides long- term protection against smallpox. Because vaccinia virus is alive when administered, it replicates for a period in the host then dies without causing overt disease (unless the individual is immune compromised).
What type of vaccine is the Botulism vaccine? {{c1::Toxoid}}

{{c1::Recombinant vector vaccine}} have Genes encoding for antigens that elicit protective immunity cloned into an avirulent or attenuated virus or bacterial vector that is then cloned into a live cell

Because the vector is viable/live, the gene products are processed both endogenously and exogenously and elicit both antibody and cell-mediated immunity. 

As with live/attenuated vaccines, caution will have to be exercised in the administration of vector vaccines because they can be virulent and potentially fatal in immunocompromised individuals.
Vaccine {{c1::Valency}} refers to the number of genera, species, or strains targeted by the vaccine

pneumococcal vaccine - 23-valent - capsules from the 23 most common strains or serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae

MMR = trivalent
{{c1::Formalin/formaldehyde}} and {{c1::gluteraldehyde}} are used in {{c2::killed}} and {{c2::toxoid}} vaccine preperation and functions {{c3::cross-linksing amino and amide groups of proteins}}

conserves basic structural integrity, however may destroy antigenic integrity 
Formaldehyde may cause hypersensitivity responses. 
The concerns over formaldehyde in vaccines center on its potential carcinogenicity in vitro.
{{c1::beta-propiolactone}} is used in {{c2::killed/ toxoid}} vaccines and fuctions by cross-links nucleic acid chains and therefore kills without affecting antigenic structure.
Live attenuated vaccinations are made through {{c2::culture attenuation}} or {{c1::heterologous animal species}}
{{c1::Adjuvants}} focus the immune response by restricting Ag dispersion

Example include: 

Alum (aluminum hydroxide, aluminum phosphate, or aluminum potassium)
ASO4: contains monophosphoryl Lipid A (to stimulate TLR4)+ alum 
ASO1B: contains monophosphoryl Lipid A (to stimulate TLR4)+
alum+QS-21
CBP1018: contains CPG1018 (synthetic DNA sequences that stimulate PRRs)
{{c1::Neomycin}} - is a topically applied antibiotic that interferes with bacterial protein synthesis by binding primarily to the 30S subunit of bacterial ribosomes
{{c1::2-Phenoxyethanol (2-PE)}} is a preservative in some vaccines
{{c1::Thimerosal}} is a preservative used in some vaccines but it may cause {{c2::hypersensitivity reactions }}

HOWEVER, several studies have shown that thimerosal may be safely administered, even to thimerosal-sensitive individuals, in the doses found in vaccines. It is not known to be a significant problem in vaccines. Many have concluded that the conditions of thimerosal delivery in routine vaccines may be sufficient to induce sensitization but insufficient to evoke elicitation.
{{c1::Specific human immune globulin (SHIG)}} preperations are made by screening Donors  for a specific high titer of antibody against a particular antigen or pathogen
For major wounds if the history of vaccination is uncertain or less than 3 doses {{c1::Tdap and TIG}} should be given
For major wounds if the history of vaccination is > 3 doses {{c1::Tdap and TIG should not be given}}
For minor wounds if the history of vaccination is uncertain or less than 3 doses {{c1::Tdap}} should be given
For minor wounds if the history of vaccination is > 3 doses {{c1:: neither Tdap nor TIG}} should be given
{{c3::Snake, Spider, botulism and Scorpion}} anti-venoms are all raised in {{c2::heterlogous species}} and therefore can have {{c1::serum sickness}} as a side effect
An advantage of monoclonal Abs is {{c1::100% of the protein injected is for the target antigen}} and therefore less MoAbs are needed for a particular affect

Disadvantages of MoAbs (Monoclonal antibodies) inclues
1) {{c1::Expensive as fuck}}
2) {{c2::Are chimeric to a certain degree (contains antigens from different organism) which can cause serum sickness}}
{{c1::Ibritumomab}} targets B-cell CD-20 on {{c2::small tumors and metastases}}
{{c1::Muromonab}} prevents allograft rejection using {{c2::anti-CD3}} and is also used to treat  type I DM using {{c2::anti-CD3}}
{{c1::Daclizumab}}, which blocks the {{c2::IL-2 receptor}} and prevents initiation of {{c3::allograft rejection }}
